input:
2. A 9-month-old male infant is evaluated for delayed milestones and progressive muscle weakness. His parents note he has lost previously acquired ability to grasp toys and now struggles to sit unsupported. Neurological examination reveals decreased muscle tone, distal limb atrophy, and absent Achilles reflexes. Ophthalmological assessment shows decreased visual responsiveness with documented bilateral optic disc pallor. Electrophysiological studies confirm a mixed motor and sensory axonal neuropathy. Brain MRI reveals mild cerebral and cerebellar atrophy without white matter abnormalities. Genetic analysis uncovers a mutation linked to infantile-onset axonal motor and sensory neuropathy-optic atrophy-neurodegenerative syndrome. Multidisciplinary management is initiated, focusing on supportive therapies and close monitoring of neurological and visual function.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: I need to be honest about what’s been happening, but I also don’t want to sound too worried or like I’m exaggerating. I should mention the main issues clearly, even if I don’t understand everything or how serious it is. I might feel scared or confused, so I’ll keep it simple and real.

ANSWER: I’m here because my baby, he’s 9 months old, and he’s not doing the things he was doing before. He can’t really hold toys anymore or sit up by himself, and I think he’s having trouble with his muscles and his eyes too. It’s making us really worried because he’s not better and seems to be getting worse.

input: 2. A 9-month-old male infant is evaluated for delayed milestones and progressive muscle weakness. His parents note he has lost previously acquired ability to grasp toys and now struggles to sit unsupported. Neurological examination reveals decreased muscle tone, distal limb atrophy, and absent Achilles reflexes. Ophthalmological assessment shows decreased visual responsiveness with documented bilateral optic disc pallor. Electrophysiological studies confirm a mixed motor and sensory axonal neuropathy. Brain MRI reveals mild cerebral and cerebellar atrophy without white matter abnormalities. Genetic analysis uncovers a mutation linked to infantile-onset axonal motor and sensory neuropathy-optic atrophy-neurodegenerative syndrome. Multidisciplinary management is initiated, focusing on supportive therapies and close monitoring of neurological and visual function.Can you tell me more about how your baby has been doing lately, including any changes you've noticed in their movements, behavior, or how they seem to be feeling overall?
output: Well, he’s not really moving like before, and sometimes he just kinda... doesn’t seem to do much at all. He used to try and grab things and hold onto stuff, but now he doesn’t seem to do that anymore, and he gets tired really easily. He’s more fussy sometimes, and I just feel like he’s not himself, but I don’t know if that’s right or what it all means.

output: Um, he’s been kinda fussy sometimes, but I don’t really know if it’s anything serious. No big fevers or throwing up that I remember. I just, I don’t know, he’s been different than before, but I don’t think he’s had any really bad illnesses.

output: He doesn't play or reach for things the way he used to, and sometimes he just looks away or gets really upset when we're trying to help him sit or hold things. It feels like he's not responding the same, and I worry because he used to do more, but now it’s like he's fading or something.

output: Um, yes, sometimes he seems a bit... off when looking at things, like he doesn't follow objects as well as he used to, and I think his eyes might move differently sometimes, but I'm not really sure if it's normal or not.

input: 2. A 9-month-old male infant is evaluated for delayed milestones and progressive muscle weakness. His parents note he has lost previously acquired ability to grasp toys and now struggles to sit unsupported. Neurological examination reveals decreased muscle tone, distal limb atrophy, and absent Achilles reflexes. Ophthalmological assessment shows decreased visual responsiveness with documented bilateral optic disc pallor. Electrophysiological studies confirm a mixed motor and sensory axonal neuropathy. Brain MRI reveals mild cerebral and cerebellar atrophy without white matter abnormalities. Genetic analysis uncovers a mutation linked to infantile-onset axonal motor and sensory neuropathy-optic atrophy-neurodegenerative syndrome. Multidisciplinary management is initiated, focusing on supportive therapies and close monitoring of neurological and visual function.Have you noticed any recent changes in your baby's muscle tone, feeding patterns, or new neurological symptoms, such as seizures or increased difficulty with eye movements?
output: Um, recently, he seems a bit more floppy and doesn’t hold his head up as well as before. Sometimes he seems a little fussy when he’s eating, and I think his eyes don’t move around as much as they used to, like he’s not tracking things the same. I haven’t seen any seizures or anything, but I’m kind of worried because he’s different.

Multidisciplinary management is initiated, focusing on supportive therapies and close monitoring of neurological and visual function.Has your baby’s mother had any issues with her vitamin B12 levels, or has your baby been exclusively breastfed without vitamin supplementation?
output: I honestly don’t remember if she had any problems with her vitamins. He’s basically been on breast milk most of the time, and I don’t think we gave him any vitamins or supplements apart from that.
